00014 #include <sstream>
00015 #include <iomanip>

00017 namespace GeographicLib {
00018 
00019   /**
00020    * \brief Convert between degrees and %DMS representation.
00021    *
00022    * Parse a string representing degree, minutes, and seconds and return the
00023    * angle in degrees and format an angle in degrees as degree, minutes, and
00024    * seconds.
00025    **********************************************************************/
00026   class DMS {
00027   private:
00028     typedef Math::real real;
00029     static int lookup(const std::string& s, char c) throw() {
00030       std::string::size_type r = s.find(toupper(c));
00031       return r == std::string::npos ? -1 : int(r);
00032     }
00033     template<typename T> static std::string str(T x) {
00034       std::ostringstream s; s << x; return s.str();
00035     }
00036     static const std::string hemispheres;
00037     static const std::string signs;
00038     static const std::string digits;
00039     static const std::string dmsindicators;
00040     static const std::string components[3];
00041     DMS();                      // Disable constructor
00042 
00043   public:
00044 
00045     /**
00046      * Indicator for presence of hemisphere indicator (N/S/E/W) on latitudes
00047      * and longitudes.
00048      **********************************************************************/
00049     enum flag { 
00050       /**
00051        * No indicator present.
00052        * @hideinitializer
00053        **********************************************************************/
00054       NONE = 0,
00055       /**
00056        * Latitude indicator (N/S) present.
00057        * @hideinitializer
00058        **********************************************************************/
00059       LATITUDE = 1,
00060       /**
00061        * Longitude indicator (E/W) present.
00062        * @hideinitializer
00063        **********************************************************************/
00064       LONGITUDE = 2,
00065       /**
00066        * Used in Encode to indicate output of an azimuth in [000, 360) with no
00067        * letter indicator.
00068        * @hideinitializer
00069        **********************************************************************/
00070       AZIMUTH = 3,
00071       /**
00072        * Used in Encode to indicate output of a plain number.
00073        * @hideinitializer
00074        **********************************************************************/
00075       NUMBER = 4,
00076     };
00077 
00078     /**
00079      * Indicator for trailing units on an angle.
00080      **********************************************************************/
00081     enum component {
00082       /**
00083        * Trailing unit is degrees.
00084        * @hideinitializer
00085        **********************************************************************/
00086       DEGREE = 0,
00087       /**
00088        * Trailing unit is arc minutes.
00089        * @hideinitializer
00090        **********************************************************************/
00091       MINUTE = 1,
00092       /**
00093        * Trailing unit is arc seconds.
00094        * @hideinitializer
00095        **********************************************************************/
00096       SECOND = 2,
00097     };
00098 
00099     /**
00100      * Convert a string in DMS to an angle.
00101      *
00102      * @param[in] dms string input.
00103      * @param[out] ind a DMS::flag value indicating the presence of a
00104      *   hemisphere indicator.
00105      * @return angle (degrees).
00106      *
00107      * Degrees, minutes, and seconds are indicated by the letters d, ', &quot;,
00108      * and these components may only be given in this order.  Any (but not all)
00109      * components may be omitted.  The last component indicator may be omitted
00110      * and is assumed to be tbe next smallest unit (thus 33d10 is interpreted
00111      * as 33d10').  The final component may be a decimal fraction but the
00112      * non-final components must be integers.  The integer parts of the minutes
00113      * and seconds components must be less than 60.  A single leading sign is
00114      * permitted.  A hemisphere designator (N, E, W, S) may be added to tbe
00115      * beginning or end of the string.  The result is multiplied by the implied
00116      * signed of the hemisphere designator (negative for S and W).  In addition
00117      * \e ind is set to DMS::LATITUDE if N or S is present, to DMS::LONGITUDE
00118      * if E or W is present, and to DMS::NONE otherwise.  Throws an error on a
00119      * malformed string.  No check is performed on the range of the result.
00120      **********************************************************************/
00121     static Math::real Decode(const std::string& dms, flag& ind);
00122 
00123     /**
00124      * Convert DMS to an angle.
00125      *
00126      * @param[in] d degrees.
00127      * @param[in] m arc minutes.
00128      * @param[in] s arc seconds.
00129      * @return angle (degress)
00130      *
00131      * This does not propagate the sign on \e d to the other components, so
00132      * -3d20' would need to be represented as - DMS::Decode(3.0, 20.0) or
00133      * DMS::Decode(-3.0, -20.0).
00134      **********************************************************************/
00135     static Math::real Decode(real d, real m = 0, real s = 0) throw()
00136     { return d + (m + s/real(60))/real(60); }
00137 
00138     /**
00139      * Convert a string to a real number.
00140      *
00141      * @param[in] str string input.
00142      * @return decoded number.
00143      **********************************************************************/
00144     static Math::real Decode(const std::string& str);
00145 
00146     /**
00147      * Convert a pait of strings to latitude and longitude.
00148      *
00149      * @param[in] dmsa first string.
00150      * @param[in] dmsb second string.
00151      * @param[out] lat latitude.
00152      * @param[out] lon longitude.
00153      *
00154      * By default, the \e lat (resp., \e lon) is assigned to the results of
00155      * decoding \e dmsa (resp., \e dmsb).  However this is overridden if either
00156      * \e dmsa or \e dmsb contain a latitude or longitude hemisphere designator
00157      * (N, S, E, W).  Throws an error if the decoded numbers are out of the
00158      * ranges [-90<sup>o</sup>, 90<sup>o</sup>] for latitude and
00159      * [-180<sup>o</sup>, 360<sup>o</sup>] for longitude and, in which case \e
00160      * lat and \e lon are unchanged.  Finally the longitude is reduced to the
00161      * range [-180<sup>o</sup>, 180<sup>o</sup>).
00162      **********************************************************************/
00163     static void DecodeLatLon(const std::string& dmsa, const std::string& dmsb,
00164                              real& lat, real& lon);
00165 
00166     /**
00167      * Convert a string to an angle in degrees.
00168      *
00169      * @param[in] angstr input string.
00170      * @return angle (degrees)
00171      *
00172      * No hemisphere designator is allowed and no check is done on the range of
00173      * the result.
00174      **********************************************************************/
00175     static Math::real DecodeAngle(const std::string& angstr);
00176 
00177     /**
00178      * Convert a string to an azimuth in degrees.
00179      *
00180      * @param[in] azistr input string.
00181      * @return azimuth (degrees)
00182      *
00183      * A hemisphere designator E/W can be used; the result is multiplied by -1
00184      * if W is present.  Throws an error if the result is out of the range
00185      * [-180<sup>o</sup>, 360<sup>o</sup>].  Finally the azimuth is reduced to
00186      * the range [-180<sup>o</sup>, 180<sup>o</sup>).
00187      **********************************************************************/
00188     static Math::real DecodeAzimuth(const std::string& azistr);
00189 
00190     /**
00191      * Convert angle (in degrees) into a DMS string.
00192      *
00193      * @param[in] angle input angle (degrees)
00194      * @param[in] trailing DMS::component value indicating the trailing units
00195      *   on the string and this is given as a decimal number if necessary.
00196      * @param[in] prec the number of digits after the decimal point for the
00197      *   trailing component.
00198      * @param[in] ind DMS::flag value indicated additional formatting.
00199      * @return formatting string
00200      *
00201      * The interpretation of \e ind is as follows:
00202      * - ind == DMS::NONE, signed result no leading zeros on degrees except in
00203      *   the units place, e.g., -8d03'.
00204      * - ind == DMS::LATITUDE, trailing N or S hemisphere designator, no sign,
00205      *   pad degress to 2 digits, e.g., 08d03'S.
00206      * - ind == DMS::LONGITUDE, trailing E or W hemisphere designator, no
00207      *   sign, pad degress to 3 digits, e.g., 008d03'W.
00208      * - ind == DMS::AZIMUTH, convert to the range [0, 360<sup>o</sup>), no
00209      *   sign, pad degrees to 3 digits, , e.g., 351d57'.
00210      * .
00211      * The integer parts of the minutes and seconds components are always given
00212      * with 2 digits.
00213      **********************************************************************/
00214     static std::string Encode(real angle, component trailing, unsigned prec,
00215                               flag ind = NONE);
00216 
00217     /**
00218      * Convert angle into a DMS string selecting the trailing component
00219      * based on the precision.
00220      *
00221      * @param[in] angle input angle (degrees)
00222      * @param[in] prec the precision relative to 1 degree.
00223      * @param[in] ind DMS::flag value indicated additional formatting.
00224      * @return formatting string
00225      *
00226      * \e prec indicates the precision relative to 1 degree, e.g., \e prec = 3
00227      * gives a result accurate to 0.1' and \e prec = 4 gives a result accurate
00228      * to 1&quot;.  \e ind is interpreted as in DMS::Encode with the additional
00229      * facility at DMS::NUMBER treats \e angle a number in fixed format with
00230      * precision \e prec.
00231      **********************************************************************/
00232     static std::string Encode(real angle, unsigned prec, flag ind = NONE) {
00233       if (ind == NUMBER) {
00234         std::ostringstream s;
00235         s << std::fixed << std::setprecision(prec) << angle;
00236         return s.str();
00237       } else
00238         return Encode(angle,
00239                       prec < 2 ? DEGREE : (prec < 4 ? MINUTE : SECOND),
00240                       prec < 2 ? prec : (prec < 4 ? prec - 2 : prec - 4),
00241                       ind);
00242     }
00243 
00244     /**
00245      * Split angle into degrees and mintues
00246      *
00247      * @param[in] ang angle (degrees)
00248      * @param[out] d degrees (an integer returned as a real)
00249      * @param[out] m arc minutes.
00250      **********************************************************************/
00251     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m) throw() {
00252       d = int(ang); m = 60 * (ang - d);
00253     }
00254 
00255     /**
00256      * Split angle into degrees and mintues and seconds.
00257      *
00258      * @param[in] ang angle (degrees)
00259      * @param[out] d degrees (an integer returned as a real)
00260      * @param[out] m arc minutes (an integer returned as a real)
00261      * @param[out] s arc seconds.
00262      **********************************************************************/
00263     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m, real& s) throw() {
00264       d = int(ang); ang = 60 * (ang - d);
00265       m = int(ang); s = 60 * (ang - m);
00266     }
00267 
00268   };
00269 
00270 } // namespace GeographicLib
00271 
00272 #endif
